MLRA_2015_4_645.JUDGMENT_NAME: TENAGA NASIONAL BERHAD v. DUNIA RAYA ENTERPRISE SDN BHD
MLRA_2015_4_645.JUDGE_NAME: Tengku Maimun Tuan Mat, Hamid Sultan Abu Backer, Badariah Sahamid JJCA

p.i: Public Utilities: Electricity - Tampering with meters - Whether proven - Written statement to consumer on amount owing - Whether complying with rules of procedure - Electricity Supply Act 1990, s 38(3), (4)

Civil Procedure: Action - Loss of revenue - Tampering with meters - Whether proven - Written statement to consumer on amount owing - Whether complying with rules of procedure - Electricity Supply Act 1990, s 38(3), (4)

HEADNOTE.p: This was the appellant's appeal against the decision of the High Court dismissing its claim against the respondent pursuant to s 38(3) Electricity Supply Act 1990 ('ESA') for loss of revenue. The appellant based its claim on the ground that the respondent had tampered with its meters placed in the basement of the respondent's shopping complex. The appellant claimed for two backdated accounts. The respondent submitted that it could not have tampered with the meters as they were in the custody and control of the appellant at all times, being placed in a locked room, which only the appellant had the keys to. Also, that the appellant did not furnish any particulars for the statement made by the appellant's representatives to base its claim on, and that only an estimated amended statement was submitted. The learned judge dismissed the appellant's claim primarily on the ground that the appellant had failed to prove that the respondent had tampered with the meters.

(1) Under s 38 ESA the appellant need not prove that it was the customer that had tampered with the meter. It was sufficient if it could show that the meter was tampered with. In terms of quantum the appellant could rely on the certified written statement to establish its case but that did not mean that the customer could not challenge the quantum. (para 6)

(2) A certified written statement must contain the particulars as stated in s 38(4) ESA before service on the customer. If the customer failed to make the payment concerned, a civil action could be taken. It was therefore a condition precedent before the commencement of a civil action based on s 38 ESA that the appellant issue a certified written statement according to law. Also, as a matter of procedural fairness, the appellant must provide details of the statement if so requested by the respondent. If details were not given, it would be difficult for the respondent to object to the statement. The court was under no obligation to admit a statement in breach of procedural rules. In the present case, the appellant's purported written statement under s 38(4) did not comply with the mandatory requirements of the law. The appellant could not rely on that statement and initiate a civil action. Furthermore, the appellant had not independently proven liability and quantum. (paras 6-7)

[5] What is important to note under s 38 is that, Tenaga is not deprived of making a claim against its customers for breach of contract and/or tort for loss of revenue in consequence of a tampered meter. If they do so they must prove that the customer tampered with the meter and in consequence Tenaga suffered loss of revenue. That is to say Tenaga must prove according to law the liability as well as quantum.

[6] However, if Tenaga relies on s 38, they need not prove that the customer tampered the meter. It is sufficient if they can show that the meter has been tampered. In terms of quantum they can rely on certified written statement to establish their case. That does not mean the respondent cannot challenge the quantum.
